quoteFirst: On Wednesday we tried all day to locate Skinski, but he avoided punishment until
quoteTime: about four o'clock in the afternoon
quoteLast: , when we finally flagged him and began to ask him questions.
title: You Can Search Me
author: Hobart, George V. (George Vere), 1867-1926

quoteFirst: They were popular features at church entertainments, Red Cross benefits, and country sociables. Often the boys, especially in the berry-picking regions, went swimming
quoteLast: , after the crates had been sent by the afternoon express.
title: Our Schools in War Time—and After
author: Dean, Arthur D. (Arthur Davis), 1872-1949

quoteFirst: We left Sandy Point on the afternoon of the 4th, and proceeded under steam to Peckett Harbour, an anchorage about twenty-five miles to the north-east of the colony. Arriving
quoteLast: , all of us who could, landed, and set off in pursuit of game. Even here, so little to the eastward of Sandy Point, the aspect of the country was completely different.
title: Cruise of the "Alert"
author: Coppinger, R. W. (Richard William), 1847-1910

quoteFirst: The wind is strong from the north. Last year we were five hours from the ambatch bush to the dubba. We shall therefore arrive to-day at
quoteLast: We have been exactly 19 1/2 hours steaming from Kutchuk Ali's station to the ambatch. We left Tewfikeeyah at 11 o'clock; we have therefore been twenty-seven days to the spot at the dubba that we should reach this evening.
title: Ismailia
author: Baker, Samuel White, Sir, 1821-1893

quoteTime: about four o'clock in the afternoon
quoteLast: the day after the fair--"John, did you buy all these things?"--the front part of the store was piled and crammed with my unwilling purchases.
title: The Blunders of a Bashful Man
author: Victor, Metta Victoria Fuller, 1831-1885

quoteFirst: It will be years before these parts of New Guinea are surveyed. With one or two narrow escapes we managed to keep clear of the hidden dangers and at
quoteTime: about four o'clock in the afternoon
quoteLast: were in sight of the Trobriands. Knowing that our cutter "_A----s_" was sure to have called at Lagrandiere, one of the islands of the group, we determined to visit it, hoping by good luck either to meet her there or learn her whereabouts.
title:
Two Years Among the Savages of New Guinea.
With Introductory Notes on North Queensland.
author: Pitcairn, W. D.

quoteTime: About four o'clock in the afternoon
quoteLast: they reached Nanaimo, and Fannin, Hugh, and Jack at once set out for the Indian village, where it was believed a canoe could be had. The brisk walk through the quiet forest was pleasant, and the Indian village of half a dozen great square plank houses interesting.
title: Jack the Young Canoeman: An Eastern Boy's Voyage in a Chinook Canoe
author: Grinnell, George Bird, 1849-1938; Deming, Edwin Willard, 1860-1942 [Illustrator]

quoteFirst: To prevent this as much as possible, I ordered all able-bodied negroes to be taken along, and warned some of the principal inhabitants that they would be held responsible for any more obstructions being placed across the creek.  We reached the admiral
quoteLast: , with no opposition save my advance-guard (Company A, Sixth Missouri) being fired into from the opposite side of  the creek, killing one man, and slightly wounding another; having no way of crossing, we had to content ourselves with driving them beyond musket-range.
title: Memoirs of General William T. Sherman — Volume 1
author: Sherman, William T. (William Tecumseh), 1820-1891

quoteFirst: Now listen to me; you will know the old woman again who came to see you this morning?' 'Yes.' 'To-morrow, or the day after at furthest, you will see her arrive,
quoteTime: about four o'clock in the afternoon
quoteLast: , on the shore opposite your island with a young girl; the old woman will make you a signal by waving her handkerchief.' 'Yes.' 'How long does it take to go from the shore to your island?' 'Twenty good minutes.
title: Mysteries of Paris — Volume 02
author: Sue, Eugène, 1804-1857

quoteLast: Mr. H., Mr. G. and Mr. B. came in from the Home, having worked all day at collecting driftwood as they came along, piling it upon end so it will not be buried in the snow, for that is the only fuel we will have this winter, and it must be gathered and hauled by the boys.
title: A Woman who went to Alaska
author: Sullivan, May Kellogg
